div1.p: Hench requests more information as to why Worden seeks certain photographs.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John E. Worden, Jr., August 9, 1951
div1.opener:
August 9, 1951
Mr. John E. Worden, Jr.
Army Medical Center
Washington 12, D. C.
My dear Mr. Worden:
div1.p:
I have your letter of August 2 requesting information regarding some
photographs related to the conquest of yellow fever by Walter Reed
and his associates in 1900. During the year I have been able to collect
quite a large number of such photographs. The most important ones
are the photographs filed in the Army Medical Museum, but I have found
others in various parts of the United States and Cuba. What would you
have in mind? Are you going to publish an article? If so you will not
need many photographs. The Reed family have given me a few photographs
of Walter Reed. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company found some old
photographs of Reed as a young man and child. The photographs of Camp
Lazear are in the Army Medical Museum. Some photographs are in the
Peabody Collection of the Welch library. However, these are small
amateur photographs.

I can supply a limited number of reprints of my article “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” printed in Hygeia in 1941. How many do you need,
and what do you want them for?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH/ac
